```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE)
```
:::


## Read in data

Read Fed Funds Rate


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ffr<-read_csv("_data/FedFundsRate.csv",
              show_col_types = FALSE)
ffr
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

:::


### Briefly describe the data

This data set is regarding various national economic variables from July of 1954 to March of 2017. It has 904 rows and 10 columns. But it also has many missing values and the recorded date is not even constant.

## Tidy Data (as needed)

Year, Month, Day are seperated. So I mutated Date column newly.(thanks to Nayan)

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(lubridate)

ffr2 <- ffr %>% 
  mutate(Date = make_datetime(Year, Month, Day))

ffr2
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 904 × 11
    Year Month   Day Federal F…¹ Feder…² Feder…³ Effec…⁴ Real …⁵ Unemp…⁶ Infla…⁷
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
 1  1954     7     1          NA      NA      NA    0.8      4.6     5.8      NA
 2  1954     8     1          NA      NA      NA    1.22    NA       6        NA
 3  1954     9     1          NA      NA      NA    1.06    NA       6.1      NA
 4  1954    10     1          NA      NA      NA    0.85     8       5.7      NA
 5  1954    11     1          NA      NA      NA    0.83    NA       5.3      NA
 6  1954    12     1          NA      NA      NA    1.28    NA       5        NA

 8  1955     2     1          NA      NA      NA    1.29    NA       4.7      NA
 9  1955     3     1          NA      NA      NA    1.35    NA       4.6      NA
10  1955     4     1          NA      NA      NA    1.43     6.7     4.7      NA

#   ⁵​`Real GDP (Percent Change)`, ⁶​`Unemployment Rate`, ⁷​`Inflation Rate`
# ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
```
:::
:::


Then, I selected date, unemployment rate, and inflation rate to checked Phillip Curve's validity. To check it I created scatter plot of unemployment and inflation.(thanks again Nayan)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pc<-select(ffr2, "Date", "Inflation Rate", "Unemployment Rate")
pc
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 904 × 3
   Date                `Inflation Rate` `Unemployment Rate`
   <dttm>                         <dbl>               <dbl>
 1 1954-07-01 00:00:00               NA                 5.8
 2 1954-08-01 00:00:00               NA                 6  
 3 1954-09-01 00:00:00               NA                 6.1
 4 1954-10-01 00:00:00               NA                 5.7
 5 1954-11-01 00:00:00               NA                 5.3
 6 1954-12-01 00:00:00               NA                 5  
 7 1955-01-01 00:00:00               NA                 4.9
 8 1955-02-01 00:00:00               NA                 4.7
 9 1955-03-01 00:00:00               NA                 4.6
10 1955-04-01 00:00:00               NA                 4.7
# … with 894 more rows
# ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(pc ,mapping=aes(x=ffr$`Unemployment Rate`, y=ffr$`Inflation Rate`)) + geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](challenge4-youngsoo-choi_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


It maybe too long period so I cannot see Phillip Curve clearly.
